sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Control structures allow you to decide which parts of your program should run and how many times they should repeat. In this tutorial, you’ll learn how to use conditional statements and loops to control the flow of your Python programs.

sections.title: Conditional Statements in Python
sections.content: Conditional statements let your program execute different code depending on whether a condition is true or false. Python provides if, elif, and else for this purpose.

sections.title: Using if, elif, and else
sections.content: You can evaluate multiple conditions using if, elif, and else. Python checks each condition in order and runs the first block that evaluates to True.

sections.title: Nested Conditional Statements
sections.content: You can place one conditional statement inside another. This is useful when decisions depend on multiple layers of logic.

sections.title: Introduction to Loops
sections.content: Loops allow you to repeat a block of code multiple times. Python has two main loop types: for loops and while loops.

sections.title: For Loops
sections.content: A for loop is typically used to iterate over a sequence such as a list, tuple, or string.

sections.title: While Loops
sections.content: A while loop continues running as long as its condition evaluates to True.
sections.code:
count = 0

while count < 5:
    print('The count is:', count)
    count += 1

sections.title: Nested Loops and Loop Control Statements
sections.content: Loops can be nested inside other loops. You can also control loop execution using break to stop a loop early or continue to skip to the next iteration.

sections.title: Summary and Next Steps
sections.content: You’ve learned how to use conditional statements and loops to control program flow in Python. These concepts are fundamental and appear in almost every real-world Python application. Next, you can combine these ideas with functions to write cleaner, reusable logic.
